column5: Some of us are deeply in tune with our emotions and desire the cleansing, cathartic release that comes with fully experiencing them, including sadness. Media that trigger those releases can be incredibly satisfying. We feel renewed and energized afterwards. Itâ€™s hard to explain to those who arenâ€™t in touch with their emotions (not implying that you arenâ€™t, OP). I also find that the more sensitive and empathetic one is, the more they connect to this sort of experience.

Here are the movies that always make me ugly cry without fail:

- A Walk to Remember
- Armageddon
- Forrest Gump
- Terms of Endearment
- Titanic
- The Perfect Storm

And a few that Iâ€™ve only watched once because they were the emotional equivalent of being hit by a bus: 

- Marley & Me
- Philadelphia
- Saving Mr. Banks
- The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas
- The Fault In Our Stars

The Fault In Our Stars was particularly brutal. I was crying from about half an hour to the end of the movie until about 10 minutes after the credits finished. Itâ€™s absolutely the saddest film Iâ€™ve ever watched. Be prepared if you decide to watch it.

I personally donâ€™t hate Buddy, but I do dislike the fact that he doesnâ€™t have the balls to own up to some of his past mistakes. I know heâ€™s been through a lot but it doesnâ€™t excuse his inability to heal wounds he caused Heather, Whitney, and many others while he was addicted.
Brilliant lol.

â€¢ Behind the Scenes

 This is Jeremy & Audrey Roloffâ€™s podcast (theyâ€™re the ones that left the TLC show Little People, Big World). At first I didnâ€™t mind it. It was kind of fun and relatable because theyâ€™re my age and going through a lot of the same life phases. But then it shifted focus into being centred almost solely around religion. These two are self-centered, arrogant, and incredibly closed-minded. If youâ€™re an evangelist Christian, youâ€™ll probably love it. Otherwise, skip this one.

â€¢ Irish History Podcast

I actually really like this podcast and plan on subscribing again at some point. The only reason I deleted it was because podcasts were taking up too much memory space on my phone and I needed to cut back. I just got rid of all the ones I wasnâ€™t listening to on a daily basis and this was one of them. Nothing bad to say about this on at all. Itâ€™s a real deep dive into Irish history and the host Finn Dwyer is great.Iâ€™m really looking forward to jumping back into it.

â€¢ Invention 

This is one of the myriad of podcasts produced by the former How Stuff Works crew (owned by Discovery before being bought by iHeartRadio a few years back). This one is hosted by Robert Lamb and Joe McCormick, who also host the more popular Stuff to Blow Your Mind. Each episode of Invention covers the history of a different item or process of the modern world. 

The reason I unsubscribed is that Invention is basically almost exactly the same as their other show. They attempted to branch out and do something different but it wasnâ€™t different at all. I decided to scrap it and stick with STBYM, which has been around for a decade and is much more interesting. Robert Lamb is insufferably boring and socially inept, but luckily Joe McCormick is the opposite and injects much needed humour and personality into each episode. I keep STBYM for the science and for Joe.

Iâ€™ve never had any issues, however thatâ€™s just my own individual experience. Others might have run into fake stuff. Again, great that youâ€™re spotlighting this for future purchasers. People take care of each other on this sub! :-)

Let â€˜em boycott! Itâ€™s been almost 20 years, ffs! Anyone who doesnâ€™t see the humour in what Dan and Justin did with that scene can bugger off. It was two seconds of the episode and it was brilliantly executed. I laughed hard and so did a lot of other fans watching. 

We live in a world now where comedy is constantly being attacked and we need to push back against that. It feels like everything is off limits sometimes. These PC Police are nothing but a vocal minority. Letâ€™s not give them more credence than they deserve.

Also, anyone who can laugh at the myriad of other potentially offensive topics Rick & Morty has taken aim at - Hitler/Nazism, cannibalism, swinging, sexual assault etc. - is completely hypocritical if they boycott the show because of a 9/11 joke. Please...ğŸ™„

I see a few people have mentioned niacinamide. If you decide to try it, be aware that people's experiences with The Ordinary's Niacinamide 10% & Zinc 1% tend to be very mixed. For some people it's a game changer, but for others it causes a lot of additional irritation. I fall into the latter group. I have very mild rosacea and the niacinamide really did not agree with my skin. It made it red, itchy and slightly hot to the touch. Just wanted to give you a heads up in case you decide to try it.
Yep, I had the same experience. It sucks because I really wanted it to work for me because it's such a good product for so many people.

I've been doing the same lately, just splashing some cold water on my face in the morning, followed by SPF and my skin's loving it so far. It's incredible how smart our skin is and how easily it regulates itself when we let it be.
I loved when Summer countered with â€œI jerk off too!â€ LOL

Just what we need right now - pyramid scheme cultists coming out of the woodwork. I got approached a couple of times by people from different MLMs (or maybe they were from the same one, Iâ€™ll never know lol) when I worked retail years ago. I can spot them a mile off now. 

As sad as it is to say this, always be weary of strangers who are *too* nice. When someone youâ€™ve never met before greets you and then, apropos of nothing, proceeds to ask you what your future career plans or goals are, theyâ€™re trying to sell you something. Youâ€™re not an asshole for thinking â€œWhy is this person being so nice to me? Why arenâ€™t they like a normal stranger, awkwardly exchanging forced pleasantries with me?â€ No, youâ€™re absolutely right to feel that way. Listen to your gut and donâ€™t let them lure you in. They prey on people who seem nice (read: impressionable). This is one of those situations in life where itâ€™s okay not to be so nice.

Hi, 31F. I'm very fair and thanks to genetics, blue veins beneath my eyes are always visible. I also deal with some purple-ish discolouration in the corners of my eyes most of the time, in the exact same area where I have persistent milia. I wish I could go back in time and figure out what I did (or didn't do) that caused the milia because I didn't always have it and now I can't get rid of it.

In terms of eye creams, I fall slightly on the side of being in favour of them. I never tried a dedicated eye product until a couple of years ago. I'd heard good things, so I decided to try the Ole Henrikson Banana Bright Eye Cream. For me, it definitely helps. The vitamin C brightens my under eye area, which helps to mask the blue veins a bit, and the moisturization it provides is lovely. My only gripe, and it's not that big a deal, is that it takes a while to absorb. It's neither helped nor aggravated my milia, but compared to when I don't use an eye cream at all, it makes a noticeable difference for me overall. 

I accepted the veins years ago because they're genetic and I know they'll never disappear. The occasional discolouration I can stave off by being more diligent with my diet, exercise, and sleep, and as for the milia, I feel like that's a battle I'll be fighting for a while to come.

A couple I'm trying out right now are Old Hollywood Realness and Classic Movie Recall.

It's now defunct, but I listened to a few episodes of one called Any Ladle's Sweet That Dishes Out Some Gravy. It focused on women's roles, both in front of the camera and behind the scenes, in old Hollywood.

Iâ€™m afraid to go to sleep sometimes if Iâ€™ve stayed up too late not because Iâ€™m afraid of sleep itself or nightmares or anything but because Iâ€™m worried Iâ€™ll sleep through my alarms in the morning. Iâ€™ve been diagnosed with Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder, so itâ€™s usually a huge struggle for me to get up in the morning, especially as I work a 9-5.

I was raised on 1% milk and itâ€™s the only kind I liked drinking before I became lactose intolerant and cut out dairy milk altogether. For me, 2% is ever so slightly too thick and makes me feel like Iâ€™m drinking fatty milk and non-fat milk is just watery and gross. 1% is the perfect middle ground.

I feel your pain on this one. My partner and I have struggled with the decision of when to start trying for a while. We don't have any debt, thankfully, but he's been career-hopping since we started dating and still hasn't settled into a job he truly loves. For the last couple of years, he's had a job that pays incredibly well but has unpredictable hours and is very high-stress. He's going through the motions at this point and is applying elsewhere. We just bought a house so financial stability is especially important right now.

What's great for you and your husband is that you're both highly educated and, from the sound of it, gainfully employed. As long as you both feel comfortable about whatever timeline you choose, I think you'll be just fine. You can continue to chip away at your student debt over the next several years and probably still be in great shape. If you guys are good with finances and have a firm grasp on your monthly and yearly budgeting, a baby will change the budget but not throw it completely off the rails.

To answer your ultimate question, I don't think there's ever an ideal time to have a baby. No one is ever as adequately prepared for it as they think they are, so we all just do the best we can. It sounds like you and your spouse have your lives together and would be in a good position to provide for another life.

My partner of 4 years and I moved into our first house at the beginning of April and are settling in nicely. We're planning on getting engaged by the end of this year, married sometime in 2021 most likely. I have incurable baby fever though, so we might have a baby before we're married. 

The plan was always to get married before kids but, honestly, my biological clock is ticking loudly now and my perspective has kind of shifted. The past year or so I've been of the mind that you can get married anytime whereas fertility has a time limit (I'm 31). Ergo, I want to get a bun in this oven ASAP lol.

So, hoping to seriously start TTC sometime next year and couldn't be more excited!

Itâ€™ll probably be one of, if not absolutely, *THE* hardest things youâ€™ll ever have to do but think about it this way: the last 3.5 years were not a waste, they were a lesson. Armed with the wisdom and strength youâ€™ve gained from this experience, you can enter your next relationship completely confident and empowered. Youâ€™ll know the warning signs to watch for because youâ€™ve been there before. Youâ€™ll listen to your gut because youâ€™ll know itâ€™s your truest guide in this life. Most importantly, youâ€™ll be able to find someone who would never dream of viewing you as â€œpropertyâ€ (whatever the fuck *that* means in this day and age...is your fiancÃ© actually aware that heâ€™s living in the 21st century, not the 15th?!), much less say it out loud. 

Your fiancÃ© has given you a gift actually. By revealing his true colours now instead of after youâ€™re married, heâ€™s giving you an opportunity to escape. You have a chance to avoid making the biggest mistake of your your life. Take it. Go out there and enjoy your 20s! Find someone who will treat you with all the respect and love you deserve.

Ohhh yes, Stacy London rocks that silver streak like nobodyâ€™s business!! I miss What Not to Wear lol. But yeah, I know exactly how you feel. My partner is a silver fox too actually. Heâ€™s 37 and has been grey since his mid 20s. Men and women alike comment all the time on how great his hair looks - and theyâ€™re right. He pulls it off incredibly well and it suits him. I found my first grey hair a few years ago at 28 and I was like â€œAhhhhh!!!!â€ It was...a moment...lol. It doesnâ€™t really bother me that much though honestly. I wish we, as women, could walk around and show our greys the way men do and be applauded for it. 

I *love* how you described it - that women who embrace their grey become invisible. Itâ€™s so true. I mean, even my 81-year-old grandma still gets her hair dyed at the salon. Our hair colour empowers us and keeps us relevant. What a strange thought. On the plus side, we get to have fun and experiment with our hair our entire lives.

Thank you!! So many people need to hear this and actually let it sink in; particularly the fact that skincare advertising is solely directed towards women. We all know it, but how often do we actually stop to think about how fucked up that is?

The double standard is sickening: men get sexier, more distinguished and desirable as they age, whereas women become less attractive, desirable and respected with each passing year.

Weâ€™re complicit in all of it by buying into the beauty industry, both literally and figuratively. Itâ€™s a multi-billion dollar a year global megalith that thrives on our collective insecurity. The most sinister thing, of course, is that they themselves create that insecurity through the advertising we canâ€™t escape. All I have to say is our society was ill long before COVID-19.

Iâ€™ve felt angry, aimless, and misguided and part of that, I think, was from not being grounded in faith.

I hope youâ€™re able to find peace, no matter how long it takes. My crisis of faith lasted for years, but I feel that it made my belief in and love for God even stronger in the end. Donâ€™t beat yourself up either. Weâ€™re all struggling right now and itâ€™s okay to not be okay, even if that means doubting your faith. Iâ€™ve been there and, trust me, itâ€™ll all work out in the end.

The sick part is that there will likely never be any answers for the families, friends and communities left behind. I remember having the same struggle when I first discovered the Enneagram. I felt like I related equally well to type 4 and type 6 descriptions. I did a few weeks of soul searching and had an epiphany one night while reading the type 4 description on the [Enneagram Institute](https://enneagraminstitute.com/type-descriptions) website for the umpteenth time. I'd read it several times but had never truly absorbed the content. This time, I felt as though my innermost motivations, fears, and desires were reflected back to me. 

A big part of my realization that I was a 4 came from my weeks of introspection and that's the best advice I can give you. Dig deep down into your soul without judgement (yes, this can be hard) and you'll figure out which type's core elements speak to you most authentically. Good luck!

You nailed it. 31F here and my professional experience has been the same. I work in advertising, a notoriously fickle industry even in boom times, and Iâ€™ve learned all of the lessons you mentioned. It took me the better part of a decade to get to my dream job three years ago. I definitely paid my dues and I feel like our whole generation has. Itâ€™s definitely taking us longer than our parents to reach certain milestones though, simply due to economic stresses, like you said.

We were raised with pie-in-the-sky expectations of the world and what life could be. I donâ€™t fault our parents and teachers for giving us that hope. I think they truly did believe - and still do believe - that weâ€™re capable of achieving all the success they did. 

What they didnâ€™t bargain for and couldnâ€™t have predicted was the fact that our lives would be shaped more by events like 9/11, the 2008 financial crisis, etc than anything else. We all studied and worked incredibly hard to get through post-secondary. Weâ€™re the most highly educated generation in history but the least gainfully employed, which is incredibly frustrating and clearly not our fault. 

To be clear, I donâ€™t blame the Baby Boomers either. The state of the world today is due just as much to forces outside of our control as it is to the ethos of our parentsâ€™ generation. Blaming the Boomers is just as ridiculous as them blaming us for all of this. Like, if weâ€™re going to play that game, every generation can blame the ones before them for contributing to certain aspects of their own misfortune, but itâ€™s ultimately a waste of time. Can they go back in time and change any of it? No they canâ€™t. Can *we*, the Millennials, do our best to make sure our own kids donâ€™t face the same challenges weâ€™re currently facing? Yes, to a degree I believe we can.

We need to look forward, not back. Iâ€™m so sick of the intergenerational pettiness.

Project Blue Book. 

The second season just finished recently on History Channel. Itâ€™s based on real events that took place in the 1950s. Professor Allan Hynek and Captain Michael Quinn of the U.S. Air Force are tasked with investigating paranormal events for Project Blue Book, a CIA-led operation during the Cold War. 

The two men each have a bit of Mulder and Scully in them. One more of a believer, the other a steadfast man of science. As time goes on, both are forced to question whatâ€™s actually real. Just like Mulder and Scully, theyâ€™re constantly being monitored by the feds, who reign them in when they get too close to discovering something pivotal.

Any Americans, like OP I presume, who are sick of their healthcare system, youâ€™re the smart ones. You look at universal healthcare elsewhere in the western world and see it for what it really is. You understand that no system is perfect but that socialized medicine is one of the greatest achievements of the modern era. For certain unfathomable reasons, the USA has not yet embraced this fact.

If youâ€™re interested in experiencing universal healthcare - because yes, you are entitled to it as a human being - weâ€™d welcome you with open arms in Canada. Our healthcare system is one of our most precious and valued institutions and it baffles us that so many people in the States donâ€™t feel the same. For those of you that do, we salute you and your progressiveness. Our doors are always open.

As OP conveyed, it comes down to morality. Frankly, anyone who thinks there should be a dollar value placed on human lives truly is an amoral individual. Especially in times like these, universal healthcare should be a no-brainer.
